nl.tue.multibrowsertest

Class TestRunner<ResultObject>

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.tue.multibrowsertest.TestRunner<ResultObject>
  • Type Parameters:
    ResultObject - The object returned by the test and reported back to the master
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Runnable

    public class TestRunner<ResultObject>
extends Object
implements Runnable
    A test-runner capable of running a standard Selenium browser test given a browser to test against, a Dimension the browser should have, a CrossBrowserTest to run and an location of the host to run the test on. The class is Runnable in order to have the ability to make the cross-browser testing environment multi-threaded. Results will be reported back to the master of this test-runner, a MultiBrowserTester. It is possible to take screenshots in a consistend way using this class, and they can be compared to tests with other browsers and dimensions in the MultiBrowserTester. After the CrossBrowserTest is finished it will return a ResultObject that will be reported back to the master.
    Author:
    Lasse Blaauwbroek

        public TestRunner(URL seleniumServer,

          org.openqa.selenium.Dimension browserDimension,

        Parameters:
        seleniumServer - The Selenium host server
        browser - The browser the test should run on
        test - The test that should be run
        master - The master to report back to
        browserDimension - The dimension the browser should have
        waitFor - If given, the test will first wait for this thread to die before actually executing the test.

    • Method Detail

      • run

        public void run()
        Runs the test by first creating a driver, then setting the view-port of the browser to the correct dimensions and then running the specified test All results and exceptions are reported back to the master. The dimensions of the view-port is approximated by first resizing the window to this dimension, then measuring the view-port with some java-script and then compensating for the window decorations. Dimensions are measured without scroll-bars.
        Specified by:
        run in interface Runnable

      • takeScreenshot

        public void takeScreenshot()
        Takes a screenshot of the current view-port of the browser, and reports it back to its master in order to compare it to screenshots taken with other test-runners. If there is a scroll-bar present, it will be hidden temporarily using some java-script. Then a screenshot will be taken of the view-port. For browsers in which the whole page is captured, the resulting image is cropped to the correct dimensions.

      • createDriver

        private void createDriver()
        Creates a driver for a given browser. The driver is augmented with screenshot support and if needed, browser specific adjustments to the driver are made.

      • setViewportDimension

        private void setViewportDimension()
                           throws MultiBrowserTesterException
        Sets the Dimension of the view-port of the WebDriver. This is done by first hiding, the scroll-bars of the view-port, then setting the body of the document to stretch over the whole view-port using java-script. Then the window is resized to the desired Dimension. Using java-script the dimensions of the view-port are measured, and the window is resized again to compensate for window decorations. If the resizing of the window to the correct dimension fails, an exception is thrown. The most likely cause is that the screen of the Selenium host is of insufficient size.
        Throws:
        MultiBrowserTesterException - If the driver was not able to set the dimension of the view-port correctly
